Quoth Manuel Amago:
> [...] The common
> topics that appear when discussing the complexity of JUnit are Suites
> and Tests, where this is just a typical instantiation of the Composite
> pattern.  [...]

Although what you say is entirely true, I think it disregards the
imho unfortunately misleading appearance of what I imagine to be
the most common case, in which several tests are bundled together
in a subclass of TestCase, from which a TestSuite is assembled on
the fly via reflection.

Since such a subclass of TestCase defines several tests, it is
easy (though wrong) to think that an instance of that subclass
performs several tests.  Then TestCase looks like the composite
level of the Composite pattern, rather than the leaf level.  It
doesn't help that the assembly of the actual -- and unrelated --
composite object from the TestCase is hidden away in the
TestRunner, whence it is unlikely to grab the mistaken user's
attention.

Of course, all of this has nothing to do with the topic of the
thread, which is JUnit's internals, not its public interface.
subject: Re: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?
